Award.AwardTitle: Chiral Crown Catalysts for Selective Rh-Catalyzed Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Joseph M. Fox of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Delaware will design synthetic catalysts that derive stereoselectivity from their larger secondary structure. In particular, he will study conformationally flexible chiral bimetallic rhodium complexes that adopt distinct secondary structures, referred to as the 'chiral crown' conformation. He will develop a diverse family of catalysts in which the crown conformation is enforced, and illustrate how these catalysts can be used to promote novel reactivity. His group will design new types of mixed ligand chiral crown complexes, and use these complexes to catalyze asymmetric CH functionalization reactions of indoles and pyrroles. He will also use these complexes to catalyze reactions of alkynes with diazoesters to give chiral butenolides via sequential ring expansion/sigmatropic rearrangement cascades.

The proposed research will have broad impact through the creation of new catalysts and patterns of reactivity that will have impact across academia and pharmaceutical research. This program will also be integrated with Undergraduate and Graduate education/training initiatives. This award will continue to support research opportunities for a diverse group of scientists, and will create research opportunities for undergraduate students for the span of the award. This award will also provide funding for high school students to participate in research experiences in his laboratory.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Joseph M. Fox of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Delaware designed synthetic catalysts that derive selectivity from their larger secondary structure, drawing inspiration from the action of enzymes.  In particular, conformationally flexible chiral bimetallic rhodium complexes were discovered that adopt a distinct secondary structure referred to as the ‘chiral crown’ structure.  The research led to discovery of a diverse family of catalysts in which the crown conformation is enforced, and showed how these catalysts could be used to promote novel reactivity. His group designed new types of mixed ligand chiral crown complexes, and used these complexes to catalyze asymmetric CH functionalization, cyclopropenation and bicyclobutanation reactions.  His group used these complexes to catalyze reactions of alkynes with diazoesters to give chiral butenolides via sequential ring expansion/sigmatropic rearrangement cascades.  Their group also demonstrated how the catalysts could be used to created cyclobutane-containing natural products, and the first asymmetric total synthesis of the natural product piperarborenine B was described. 

The broader impact of the work included the creation of new catalysts and patterns of reactivity that will have impact across academia and pharmaceutical research. This program was also integrated with undergraduate and graduate education/training initiatives, supporting the Ph.D. training of a diverse group of scientists, and creating research opportunities for undergraduate students throughout the span of the award.  Outreach into a local K-8 school was carried out to introduce elementary students to chemistry, crystallography and microscopy.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2017
Modified by: Joseph M Fox

In particular, conformationally flexible chiral bimetallic rhodium complexes were discovered that adopt a distinct secondary structure referred to as the ?chiral crown? structure. The research led to discovery of a diverse family of catalysts in which the crown conformation is enforced, and showed how these catalysts could be used to promote novel reactivity. His group designed new types of mixed ligand chiral crown complexes, and used these complexes to catalyze asymmetric CH functionalization, cyclopropenation and bicyclobutanation reactions. His group used these complexes to catalyze reactions of alkynes with diazoesters to give chiral butenolides via sequential ring expansion/sigmatropic rearrangement cascades. Their group also demonstrated how the catalysts could be used to created cyclobutane-containing natural products, and the first asymmetric total synthesis of the natural product piperarborenine B was described. The broader impact of the work included the creation of new catalysts and patterns of reactivity that will have impact across academia and pharmaceutical research. This program was also integrated with undergraduate and graduate education/training initiatives, supporting the Ph.D. training of a diverse group of scientists, and creating research opportunities for undergraduate students throughout the span of the award.
